dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: Let's go to your house.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I don’t want to go to my house.

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: Where do you want to go then?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I don't know. Someplace else. Maria gazes up at the top of the building and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How about up there?

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: (looks up) On the roof? Why do you wanna go up there?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Why not? ... Come on. It’s not that high.

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: What are you crazy? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (fixes him) See how you treat me? You’re a drag.

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: Let’s not get started with this, OK?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: If I go up there will you follow me?

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: (reticent) If I go, are we gonna do it up there? Maria smiles. She turns and takes a good look at the back the building. She puts her foot on a rock and pulls herse up to a first-floor window-sill. She finds a small ledge continues to scale up. Juan looks sure she won’t make it up. Maria concentrates what she's doing - never looking down. She pulls herself up to a second-floor window, but then g stuck about six feet below the roof.

dialogues.speaker: JUAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come down. We’ll go to your place. Maria places her foot on a very small protrusion and push up - she SLIPS but grabs the edge of the roof just in tim and pulls herself up. Juan stares up in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (smiles, looking down) Come on. Your turn.

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: No way.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Come up - I have something to tell you.

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: Come down.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: No. Beat. Juan looks around, at a loss for what to do.

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: You know what then, I’m taking off. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (exasperated) Then go. I'm not coming down.

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: Fine. You can come down the same way you went up - alone. I’11 see ya. Juan starts to walk away down the hill. Maria watches him go, down toward a small, isolated town ringed by mountains.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. BEDROOM — BEFORE DAWN In a small bedroom with lime-green walls and two single b Maria lies ASLEEP with her walkman next to her pillow. On the wall above her are torn-out magazine pictures of vari teen idols, salsa stars, and a pink cartoon teddy-bear. Maria’s mother JUANA calls from the other room,

dialogues.speaker: JUANA, (0S)
dialogues.text: Maria. Get up. INT. BATHROOM — BEFORE DAWN A precarious electric water-heating element mounted on th shower-head, with wires sticking out of it, shifts into t On position. Maria puts her head fully under the water. INT. KITCHEN / MAIN ROOM — BEFORE DAWN PACHO, one year old, is CRYING on his back on a tattered couch in the main room of the small house. Maria’s sister DIANA, 19, stands over him, pressing down on his stomach. ROSITA, Maria’s grandmother, moves to and from the crampe kitchen setting out cups of hot chocolate and rolls. JUAN 40, is already dressed and folding laundry.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: His stomach is hard. I’m really worried. Maria comes in combing her hair.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: What are you doing? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: He hasn’t shit in like two days. He’s really constipated.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Whatever. He’ll go when he goes. Don’t worry about it.

dialogues.speaker: JUANA
dialogues.text: Maria, don’t brush your hair in the dining room please.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: He’s cranky because he’s got someone kneading his stomach like a ball of dough. (tickling Pacho) Isn’t that right? Huh? Isn’t that right? Maria picks Pacho up and holds him over her head. him and catches him.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: (taking him back) You're scaring him.

dialogues.speaker: JUANA
dialogues.text: Give him to me.

dialogues.speaker: ROSITA
dialogues.text: (setting down hot chocolate) Maria, sit. Juana takes the baby and gives Diana a blanket.

dialogues.speaker: JUANA
dialogues.text: Mama, will you fix a tea for him?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Those teas aren’t gonna do anything for him.

dialogues.speaker: ROSITA
dialogues.text: Take him to the doctor this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: No Grandma, I don’t trust that guy.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (gets up) She throws He doesn’t need to go to the doctor. The kid is fine. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maria goes into the kitchen and opens the fridge.

dialogues.speaker: ROSITA
dialogues.text: What are you looking for?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I don’t feel like bread. I want something else. Maria cuts a piece of pork sausage for herself.

dialogues.speaker: ROSITA
dialogues.text: That's your breakfast? EXT. ROAD — DARK MORNING Maria, Juana and Diana walk along a dark, dusty road befo dawn. The only light comes from the windows of other hous they pass. They turn onto a PAVED STREET and stop at an arbitrary sp on the sidewalk and wait with several other people. There a minimum of ambient morning light; it’s cold, people hud A creaky, old SCHOOL BUS lumbers up and everyone files on except for Maria. Juana kisses Maria’s cheek and gets on.

dialogues.speaker: JUANA
dialogues.text: See you later, honey. The bus pulls away and Maria continues to wait. INT. MOVING BUS (ANOTHER) — VERY EARLY MORNING Maria sits by the window with BLANCA, also 17 but heavier than Maria. The bus lurches along. The seats are full of other people (mostly women), but there is no conversation only the sound of the driver's tinny radio. Blanca has her head on Maria’s shoulder. Maria stares out the passing farmland and cows. EXT. PLANTATION GATEHOUSE — LATER Maria and Blanca get off the bus and merge into a small s of people who funnel through a tall steel gate past a uniformed guard with steel-toed boots and a shotgun. On t other side, the grounds are landscaped and spotless.  INT. CHANGING ROOMS — CONTINUOUS Maria, Blanca and about two dozen other women put on blue jumpsuits over their clothes, along with thick, rubber bo INT. EATING ROOM — CONTINUOUS In a large room with long wooden tables and benches, abou hundred workers eat breakfast. There is a din of conversation. At one table, Blanca eats a roll as Maria interrogates her.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: So did you meet him?

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: I waited by the plaza but he never came.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? He didn't show up?

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: Well it wasn't a real date. He said he might be there.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (laughing) How long did you wait?

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: Don't laugh.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I'm not laughing. How long did you wait?

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter. He wasn’t really my type... Anyway... You see that guy over there? They both turn and look at a GUY in a green jumpsuit sitt two tables away. He makes eye contact with Blanca and SMI

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He smiles at me like all the time. The two of them GIGGLE uncontrollably.  INT. BATHROOM — LATER Maria stands at the basin of the plantation bathroom. She splashes water on her face and rinses her mouth. INT. FLOWER PLANTATION — LATER In a vast greenhouse, rows and rows of tall pink-rose pla extend into the distance. A space-man wearing a thick rub suit, a rubber face mask and a rubber head-covering walks through spraying a fine mist of chemical fumigants onto t flowers. Elsewhere in the same greenhouse women clip rose This is a high-volume flower plantation. MARIA works in t warehouse — an immense hangar with a high roof and about eighty workers all in blue jumpsuits. There are flowers everywhere - bundles of reds, yellows, oranges, and viole The whole place is a hive of activity: some workers guide large carts on a rail-system into the warehouse; some mea and classify the roses into bundles; some place the bundl in large boxes for shipment abroad. It is a tightly regimented operation. Maria wears thick rubber gloves and stands in front of a splintering plywood board. Next to her is a huge bunch of 100 red roses. One by one, she takes the roses, examines quality of the buds, measures the length, and then with a quick, violent jerk she pulls them over an open blade to strip off the thorns. It's a tedious, repetitive action. She is one in a line of twenty people doing the same work She catches a thorn in her thumb and stops to examine it through the hole in the tip of her glove. Her skin is dot with thorn scars. She’s sweating profusely and she wipes forehead with her sleeve. A SUPERVISOR walks from station to station tallying each worker's output on a clipboard. In another aisle, about twenty feet away, Blanca has the of bundling roses. She sets down corrugated paper and the one by one carefully arranges and wraps the flowers, stap the bundle shut and labels it - then starts all over agai Maria stares at the supervisor, who is now several statio up. She has paused in her work again and is watching everything else in the room with a removed, critical star She continues to perspire and looks physically ill. She raises her hand, trying to get her supervisor’s attention (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the supervisor happens to look up he sees Maria's hand the air, sighs and makes his way back to her.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Can I go to the bathroom?

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: Again?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I don't feel well.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: You've already been twice this morning. You're under by four bins this hour, three last hour. How are you going to catch up if you keep going to the bathroom? He stares at her expectantly.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Please. I'll be quick.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: Do you know what it's like for me always having to look over your shoulder, Maria? You think it's fun for me? I have eighty- four workers in this section and everyone else puts their head down and does their job. But with you, it's like this constant game of tug-of-war just to get you to make quota. At this point, I... All of the sudden Maria VOMITS directly on the flowers, splattering her supervisor slightly.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What the hell is wrong with you?! This is disgusting. Look at this. What the hell? Maria doesn’t dare look up at him.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look at these flowers. What are you gonna do about these? Huh? What are you gonna do? She just stares at the flowers blankly. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (exasperated) Pick those up. Maria scoops up the bundle of flowers in her arms - vomit all. With Blanca and the rest watching, the supervisor le her over to a large BASIN.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Set them there. Maria sets the flowers on a cart. He picks up a HOSE with spray nozzle and twists it until it shoots a fine mist. SUPERVISOR (cont'd) (passing her the hose) Wash them off. Maria picks up a rose and sprays it off.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Be careful with the bud.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: But they're already ruined.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: I don’t care. Wash them.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I need to go to the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: (really pissed) You want to go to the bathroom, then you can go on your lunch break... Or you can go right now and keep walking out the door. (he stares her down) I want all these flowers clean. And when you're done, you’re gonna go back to your station and make up the bins you owe me. Understood? The supervisor marches off, leaving Maria there - fuming. EXT. TOWN, STREETS — DAY Maria sits on a park bench and picks at her lunch, as a g of kids her age, dressed in school uniforms, passes by. S makes eye contact with one but they move on past. She che the time.  10. EXT. STREET — AFTERNOON In town. Maria walks up the street.

dialogues.speaker: JUANA, (0S)
dialogues.text: Maria! Maria sees her mother at a small store buying fruits and vegetables. She crosses over to her. Juana pays for the two bags of groceries and puts a few c of change in her pocket. She picks up the bags and the tw of them walk on in silence. INT. PHARMACY — CONTINUOUS It’s a small place with the drugs on the wall behind the counter. Diana watches as a WOMAN removes foil-wrapped TABLETS from a box and counts them out. Juana enters, trailed by Maria.

dialogues.speaker: JUANA
dialogues.text: Is everything OK?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: It’s 9,600. Do you have any money?

dialogues.speaker: JUANA
dialogues.text: (to Maria) Lend your sister the money.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Why do I have to pay for it?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: It’s for Pacho. He started vomiting.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: So? Where’s your money?

dialogues.speaker: JUANA
dialogues.text: Maria!

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I give up practically all of what I make and Diana doesn’t put in any of hers. And now I’m supposed to pay for Pacho’s medicine too? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JUANA
dialogues.text: Maria don’t start! Give your sister the money. Juana glares at her daughter. Maria finally digs into her pocket and hands over the money. JUANA (cont'd) You can keep the extra nine-thousand six- hundred when you get paid at the end of the month. I don’t know why everything always has to be so difficult with you. Maria watches Diana pay. And then, as if trying to get ba at them, she says,

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Well, there’s not going to be a next paycheck... Because I quit.

dialogues.speaker: JUANA
dialogues.text: What? When?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Today.

dialogues.speaker: JUANA
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: They wouldn’t let me go to the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: JUANA
dialogues.text: At all?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: It’s not just that. I don’t like the way they treat me. So I quit.

dialogues.speaker: JUANA
dialogues.text: What are you going to do? The woman behind the counter looks very uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: You're really fucking stupid.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Why don’t you shut up.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Don’t tell me to shut up! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With that, 12. (2)

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: You don’t know how they treated me.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: You could have put up with it. You’re an idiot...

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (overlapping) Why do I have to put up with it? Why am I always the one to put up with it all?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: (overlapping) ...Why don’t you think of the family for once.

dialogues.speaker: JUANA
dialogues.text: Enough! Quiet, both of you! (beat) Maria, you have to go back and ask for your job back.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: No. I’m not going back.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Then what are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I’1l find something else.

dialogues.speaker: JUANA
dialogues.text: There’s nothing but flowers around here. At least it’s a decent job.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Oh please, what’s decent about it?

dialogues.speaker: JUANA
dialogues.text: Maria! You have to go back!

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Didn't you hear me? I’m not going back... I’m not! Maria storms out of the pharmacy and leaves them standing there.  13. EXT. PLAZA — EARLY EVENING Maria sits by the plaza fountain with Juan and Blanca and group of about five other girls and guys crowded around. Juan's got a BOTTLE of aguardiente and everyone is laughi except Maria, who hasn’t shaken her bad mood.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: (laughing) You should have seen the look on the supervisor’s face... He was completely covered in it...

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: This deserves a toast. Juan pours a shot for Maria in a little plastic cup.

dialogues.speaker: JUAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: To Maria! Because she kicks ass! She sips it, winces and then swallows the rest in one gul

dialogues.speaker: SMASH CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. OUTDOOR FIESTA — NIGHT A small rocket whizzes into the air and EXPLODES. On a si street off the plaza, there’s a small fiesta going on - w a little band of a dozen local guys (in uniform) playing slightly sloppy, but very energetic salsa - and a crowd o about forty people of all ages - some dancing, some watch Maria and Blanca dance up a storm together - Maria dancin lead. She’s a very good dancer, very lively and quite sex Most of all, she just has a good time - giggling and laug with Blanca. Juan and the guys are sitting on the curb working their way steadily through the bottle of aguardie The music stops and all the dancers fan themselves off - walks among the band members pouring each a shot of liquo

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (to Blanca) Hey there’s your boyfriend. Blanca follows Maria’s gaze and sees the SMILING GUY from work talking with a FRIEND. Sure enough, he makes eye contact with Blanca and smiles. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: (giggling and turning away) Oh my god.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: You have to dance with him.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: No way! Hearing that, Maria grabs Blanca’s wrist and leads her ri over to the Smiling Guy and his Friend.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: SMILING GUY
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I’m Maria. This is Blanca.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: (beet red) Oh my god.

dialogues.speaker: SMILING GUY
dialogues.text: I’m Felipe. This is my cousin Franklin.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Hi. Unlike Felipe, Franklin is dressed stylishly, with a hip shirt, designer jeans and a gold chain. Next to him, Feli looks downright meek.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Blanca wants you to ask her to dance.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Go for it.

dialogues.speaker: FELIPE
dialogues.text: (smiling) Do you want to dance?

dialogues.speaker: ...OK.
dialogues.text: Felipe leads Blanca out into the dance area as the band strikes up. Maria watches them dance and then walks over Juan. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Juan, I want to dance. Juan is clearly too drunk to dance and more interested in guy friends. He takes her in his arms and mock dances drunkenly in a circle, laughing. She breaks away annoyed. MARIA (cont'd) What’s wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: (drunk) What... why? She walks away and stands watching Blanca and Felipe.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (out of nowhere) Wanna dance? Maria considers it, glances toward Juan... FRANKLIN (cont'd) What do you say?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: ...Sure. Franklin leads her out and the two of them dance. The mor she dances, the more into it Maria gets - looking over at Juan occasionally - as if she were dancing to spite him. EXT. TOWN — DAY Maria walks the dirt road down the hill and into town. She walks by several store fronts, looking occasionally inside. Her gait is slow and not particularly determined. INT. MUSIC SHOP — DAY Maria steps into a small music shop - basically just a gl case with various CD’s, and racks full of cassettes on ei wall. A MAN catalogues boxes of music as Latin rap plays a small stereo. He nods at Maria - they seem to recognize each other. She takes a tape off the wall and examines it

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: How much is it? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (turns the music down) Fifteen thousand, two hundred. Maria puts it back on the wall. She watches the man work.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: You have a lot of work.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: I have to catalogue everything, keep track of what I sold, what I didn’t. Maria contemplates asking him for a job... but the store obviously a one-man operation. INT. CHURCH — DAY Maria comes into the Catholic CHURCH where a couple of ol women talk quietly in the pews. She kneels down, crosses herself, mutters a Hail Mary, and then adds her own, sile request. EXT. MOTORBIKE REPAIR SHOP — LATER Maria and Blanca walk up to an outdoor garage that is pac with mopeds and motorcycles. JUAN is squatting next to a mechanic watching him work.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Juan.

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: (looks up) In a minute.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Come on. (to Blanca) I’1l see you later. Blanca kisses Maria’s cheek and leaves as Juan finally crosses to the front and gets his bicycle. He and Maria cross the street to... EXT. SAUSAGE STAND / PARK — LATER A small stand serving arepas across from a park. Maria an Juan each take an arepa and a Coca-cola. Juan pays and ta the change. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They walk over to the park and sit on the grass and eat. They don’t have any conversation at all while they eat - just chew in silence. At a certain point Maria stops and watches Juan take another bite - he’s absorbed in chewing

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I have something to tell you.

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: ...-I think I’m pregnant. He looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: You’re not fucking with me, right?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I missed my last two periods and I’ve been feeling sick.

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: What are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: Who else knows?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Only you.

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: No-one else?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Who else do you think I told? The whole world?

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: I don't know. Maybe Blanca, since she seems to know everything before me...

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (cutting him off) No Juan, Blanca doesn’t know. Long silence... Very long silence. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: Maria... Do you want to get married?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (laughs nervously) Are you joking?

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Where would we live?

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: In my house. Where else?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: There are like ten people living in your house. You share your bedroom with your brother.

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: What do you suggest?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: My house would be better.

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: Right, a lot better! A guy living in his girlfriend’s house? No way, not that Maria.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: You're really fucking stupid, you know that?

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: Stupid? Your family hates me. How do you expect me to live there? We can live at my house. (beat) I don’t see why you don’t want to get married. I’m stepping up to this... Maria takes a beat - stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Juan, do you love me?

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: (groans) Not this again. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Look me in the eye and tell me you love me... What kind of person are you? You want to marry a woman you don’t love? A woman who doesn’t love you? What kind of marriage is that? How long’s it gonna be before you're sleeping with some other girl? A month?

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: You know that’s not gonna happen.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I don’t want the same thing to happen to me that happened to my sister.

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: (attacking) I hate to break it to you but your sister was a fucking idiot who slept with the first guy that walked by...

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Shut up!

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: .-.and left her with a kid.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: You can’t talk about my sister like that.

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: You know I’m not going anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: That doesn’t change anything. I’m not Marrying you.

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: Well you’re gonna have to.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: No, Juan. I don’t have to do anything.

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: See how you are? You’re stubborn.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: And you're an idiot. A loser. (beat) I’m not even in love with you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: ...Me neither.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (stares at him) Perfect. Maria gets up and walks off through the park. INT. MARIA'S BEDROOM — MIDDLE OF THE NIGHT Maria sits up in bed playing with one of Pacho’s stuffed animals. She rolls on her side and stares over at her sister, asleep with Pacho. Maria grips at her sheet - ang frustrated, frightened. EXT. STREET IN TOWN — DAY Maria waits at a BUS STOP with three or four WOMEN. FRANKLIN rides by - they make eye contact - he makes a U- and pulls up on his motorcycle.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: To the city.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Hop on. I'll give you a ride.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: To Bogota?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Sure. Maria gets on and puts her arms around Franklin's waist.  21. EXT. MOVING MOTORCYCLE — CONTINUOUS Maria and Franklin ride through the streets. The scenery changes as they go from the center of town and then into expanse of open country. Taking curves faster and faster. Maria is clearly getting a rush being on the back of Franklin's motorcycle, the wind in her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At a juice stand by the side of the road, the girl behind counter scoops fruit into a blender.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: I like the way you dance.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Really? You too.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: I didn’t think people around here could dance. I thought they were all stiff.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: ...Where are you from?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: I’m from a little town called Santa Rosa de Cabal. About ten minutes from Pereira. You know it?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: They have some great hot springs there. I’'1l take you sometime.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Yeah? Franklin flashes her a smile. Maria looks away, blushing. MARIA (cont'd) (beat) So why are you here?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: ...Various reasons. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The girl sets down two glasses of juice. Franklin takes h and walks toward the little tables on the grass behind th stand. Maria follows. FRANKLIN (cont'd) ...It was nothing. I just had to get away for a while. I had some problems and things started heating up. As soon as it all calms down I’m going back... (beat) .--SO, what are you going to Bogota for?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I have a friend who works there. She works for this rich family, in their house. She’s gonna help me out getting a job. Franklin begins to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t laugh.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry... It’s just that you’re way too pretty to be working as a maid. Way too cute to be getting dressed up in a hat and apron. Those people’ll treat you like shit.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (defensive) ..-Anyway, I was just gonna check it out. It wasn’t definite. She moves away from him - sits at one of the little table

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (studies her, sits) You lost your job at the plantation, right?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Who told you?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: ...-Felipe...

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: That's a lie. They didn’t fire me.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Oh no? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: You've got bad information. They didn’t fire me - I walked.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (beat) Listen, if you’re looking for work I might be able to hook you up...

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Hook me up?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: It just depends how bad you need the money. I know of a good job... Traveling...

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Traveling where?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: To the United States.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: What's the job?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (beat) Working as a mule... You know what a mule is, or not? Maria looks away. She clearly knows. FRANKLIN (cont'd) It’s a cool job. You go, hand off the stuff, get your cash. And that’s it... Like winning the lottery.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Yeah, but it’s dangerous, right?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: How many mules do you know?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Me? None.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Well, I know a bunch. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: What about the ones on the news? The ones in prison far away. What about them?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (laughs) Those are the ones who want to be famous. They get caught, get on TV, everyone sees them and they become famous.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (doesn’t laugh) Well I don’t want to be famous.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: I know a guy who can set it all up. Takes care of the papers, makes the arrangements... Maria looks away - nervous. Franklin reads her immediatel FRANKLIN (cont'd) You know what - forget about it. (stands) Let's go. He starts to walk toward his motorcycle. Maria hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Wait. (he turns) ...How much would I get? Hold on Maria.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bogota is loud and chaotic - buses clog the streets, horn blare, waves of people crowd the sidewalks. With Maria’s arms around his waist Franklin weaves in and of city traffic and pulls up in front of a bar on a sidestreet in an uncertain neighborhood. INT. BAR — DAY It's a dimly-lit place with a pool table at the back and tables along the wall opposite the bar. It’s filled almos entirely with MEN, all older. Maria looks rather uncomfortable as she follows Franklin in. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: You want something to drink...? (to the bartender) Give me a beer and a soda for her... (to Maria) I’m gonna talk to this guy. I'’11 just be a minute. He leaves Maria at the bar and heads to the back table wh a MAN sits with the only other WOMAN in the place. Frankl shakes the man's hand and points to Maria. Maria sips her soda. Franklin comes back over and waits with Maria. A moment later, the woman at the far table gets up. She makes very definite eye contact with Maria as she walks out.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on. Franklin introduces Maria to JAVIER, a well-groomed man o about 60 with a gold chain, an ironed shirt and a cane leaning up against the table. He effects an incredibly paternal tone, calming but also intimidating.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: Sit down. Maria sits opposite him. Franklin pulls up a third chair. JAVIER (cont'd) So, you're a friend of Franklin’s. And how do you know each other? Maria falters - looks to Franklin.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (jumping in) She's a friend of the family. On my cousin’s side.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: Uh huh... And you’re looking for work?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: Since when?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: About two weeks. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: And where were you working before?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: In a flower plantation.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I didn't get along with my boss... so I left.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: Rebellious then?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: You don’t have a problem taking directions, orders?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: Do you get scared easily?

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Eighteen.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: Boyfriend?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (hesitates) No.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: Yes or no? He looks at Franklin.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: No. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: And how’s your system?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: My system?

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: I mean how’s your stomach? Do you have problems with diarrhea, constipation, digestive problems?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: Do you eat a lot?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Normal. Javier takes a beat. Examines her. Maria doesn’t flinch.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: Well then... We’re going to give you several rolls of film. We’1ll send you to New York... Actually to New Jersey - a small town next to New York. Once you go through Customs you'll be met by our people. They will take you to a safe place. We'll develop the rolls. And in five, six days you'll be back here with all your money taking care of your problems.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: How much do I get?

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: We’1l give you a hundred dollars a roll. A girl your size you could make five or six thousand depending on how much you carry. Keep in mind we have to take care of your documents. Meaning that after we deduct the expenses for your passport and visa and the other papers you'll get about seven or eight million pesos.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (hesitates) What if I get caught? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: And why would you get caught? Unless you get off the plane trembling like a leaf. Then they’1l catch you. Obviously. But no worries. Those gringos don’t know a thing. (leans in) But once your decision is made there’s no turning back. You can’t tell anyone. Understand? Javier stares hard at Maria.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: Now, I know you’re in a difficult situation. And I don’t want you making this decision under any kind of pressure. (reaching into his pocket) So I want to give you this so you can take care of a few things... He slides several BILLS across the table.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (eyes the money) ..-No, really it’s not necessary.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: (studies her) ..-No, no, no. No strings attached. Maria stares at the money on the table. EXT. STREET / BUS STOP — LATER Maria walks across the busy street and stops at the bus s Among the people waiting for the bus, Maria recognizes th WOMAN who was sitting at Javier's table in the bar. A mom later the BUS rolls up and they all get on. INT. BUS — CONTINUOUS Maria sees a free seat next to the WOMAN. She sits. The woman recognizes Maria but neither of them says anything. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: You were in the bar, right? (no response) My name is Maria. The woman glances at Maria, then looks away.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I’m Lucy. LUCY looks to be about 24. She's dressed nicely — not fan just more stylish than Maria. But from the way she carrie herself and talks she's clearly from the same class as Ma

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Do you work for Javier...? Is it hard?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: (not making eye contact) It's not easy but it's not too difficult either... How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Seventeen. I said eighteen, though.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: (looks at Maria) You just have to be prepared and know how to do it right. Maria takes this in. INT. MARIA’S HOUSE — DAY Maria comes home. Diana is folding clothes at the table. Maria walks right past her toward the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Where have you been?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I went to the city to ask Jessica to find me work.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: (following Maria) And?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: And nothing. It’s none of your business. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Don’t tell me it’s none of my business.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: It isn’t.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: You didn’t find anything. You’d tell me if you found something... You have to go back to the plantation and ask for your job back.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: No, I don’t.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: It’s not fair to mom. You know how hard it is for her and now you’re making things even worse.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Get off my back.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: (getting emotional) Don’t tell me to get off your fucking back. Pacho got a hundred and six fever today.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: He’s your kid.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: I know he’s my kid. So?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: So, he’s your responsibility.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: (yelling) We’re all equal in this house. We all have to pull our weight. You have to get a job.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Well, I already got one.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: What job? Cut the shit. Maria stares at Diana. She then reaches into her pocket a pulls out the money Javier gave her. Diana’s eyes widen. Maria peels off a few bills and throws them down. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: At least I put in my share. Maria storms out of the kitchen and into her room where s flops onto her bed, fuming. She SLAMS the door. EXT. STREET, A NEARBY TOWN — DAY Maria walks up the street in another town, slightly bigge than her own. She knocks on the door of a concrete house slightly nicer than her own. The door opens and it’s LUCY

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Hi. INT. LUCY’S HOUSE — DAY Lucy’s house is nice - spacious though vacant-feeling wit large table and chairs, and a relatively new hi-fi. Maria sits alone. Lucy comes in from the kitchen with a small b full of GRAPES. She sits.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Here. (hands Maria a grape) Hold it in your mouth. Maria puts it in her mouth and holds it there. LUCY (cont'd) Just hold it. Let it slide to the back. All the way. Now open your throat. Maria gags — then bites into the grape and swallows it.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You have to practice with the grapes. Lucy passes her the bag of grapes. Maria picks one out.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: You can swallow that? Lucy puts a grape in her mouth and swallows it whole. Mar stares in horrified awe.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: You can't eat anything for the last twenty-four hours. Your stomach has to be totally empty. They'll lie about how many you have to swallow. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: How many will it be?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: For someone your size, maybe sixty or seventy pellets.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Oh my god.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Be glad you're little. Big guys swallow like ninety or a hundred... Make sure they're well wrapped. If even one of them opens up inside you you'll die. Not as fast as cocaine. Cocaine will make your heart explode immediately. Heroin takes longer, but you still die unless you get the right medicine. Maria’s eyes widen.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wear nice clothes. Nothing flashy, just something nice - so you don’t look like a peasant. They may ask you questions in the airport. Javier will tell you what to say.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: How many times have you done this?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: ...Two.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: And it went OK?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: .-.I'm still here. (beat) The first time I did it I thought I wanted to go see my sister. She lives in New York. I haven’t seen her in four years. But then I got there and I realized, What am I going to tell her? How am I going to explain how I got here? I love her but we're really different, you know? She would kill me if she knew I was doing this. The second time I did it I went and saw where she lives but I couldn’t knock on the door. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: What is America like?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: ..-Straight. Everything’s in perfect squares. INT. BATHROOM — MIDDLE OF THE NIGHT Maria stands in front of the mirror and places a grape in mouth. She tries to swallow it and GAGS. She tries again. She looks very nervous - almost on the verge of tears. EXT. YARD — DAY In the yard behind her house Maria is washing laundry by hand. Blanca sits watching her.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: So how’s that thing?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: What thing?

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: Your job? What do you have to do?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (fixes her) I told you not to talk about it. Blanca watches her a beat and Maria goes to hang a sheet. then opens her purse and pulls something out.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: Maria... Maria, look at me! Maria finally looks over. Blanca puts a GRAPE in her mout Maria stares at her in shock as she tries to swallow it. gags and spits it out.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: I’m going to be a mule. I talked to Franklin and he arranged it.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (looks at Blanca) You what? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: You heard me. Why not?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Because you can’t... you won’t make it.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: Well, I’m doing it. I already told them.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Blanca, what the hell...?

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: It’s five thousand dollars, Maria. Do you know how much that is in pesos? I figured it out. It’s like ten million. I can buy my family a house with that.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: You can’t go.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: You know what? I don’t need your permission. I can do what I want.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Do you realize what you're saying...? Blanca you have to tell them you’re not going.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: No... Anyway, I can’t now. I already said yes. Blanca looks trapped. Maria turns away, annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: ...Do you know what you’re going to tell your family?

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: Do you?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. BEDROOM — EVENING

dialogues.speaker: JUANA
dialogues.text: I don’t understand. You’re going all the way to Chiquinquira? To work as a secretary? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Juana stands in the doorway of Maria and Diana’s bedroom, watching as Maria folds clothes and puts them into a smal suitcase. Diana sits on her own bed.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I already told you...

dialogues.speaker: JUANA
dialogues.text: Well tell me again.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I got it through Blanca’s aunt.

dialogues.speaker: JUANA
dialogues.text: But you don’t know anything about working in an office.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (crossing away from her mother) What, you don’t think I’m smart enough?

dialogues.speaker: JUANA
dialogues.text: I didn’t say that. Juana sits at the foot of Maria’s bed. She glances to Dia clearly distraught - then watches Maria continue to go through her clothes. JUANA (cont'd) I just don’t understand why you have to go so far away... Maria... Maria finally looks at her mother. They share a beat. The both clearly feel uncomfortable, but Maria buries her uncertainty with a distant resolve. EXT. PLAZA — MID-MORNING Her hair pulled back and her face made up, Maria is dress in a nice blouse and skirt — clearly her nicest outfit - she walks down into town carrying her suitcase. She sits on a bench on the edge of the town square. She looks to the center of the plaza and sees JUAN with his bicycle standing amongst friends. He turns and they make contact. After a moment of hesitation, he rides over.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (stands, awkward) Hi. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: How are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: Fine. You?

dialogues.speaker: OK.
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: I need my tapes my back.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: ...Sure. She opens her walkman, ejects the tape and hands it him. Then she goes into her bag and pulls out a handful of tap She gives him all but one, which she puts back in her bag MARIA (cont'd) (beat) Do you want the walkman back?

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: That was a present. They stare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: JUAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You look nice.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Thanks. Just then, FRANKLIN rides up on his motorcycle and stops. Maria looks enormously uncomfortable. Juan and Franklin l at each other but no-one makes any attempt at introductio

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: (finally) I gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I'll see you later. Juan gets on his bike and rides off with the tapes in one hand. Maria watches him go. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (breaking her moment) You ready? He gets her suitcase and puts it on the back of his motorcycle. Maria gives a final look at Juan as she climb on. EXT. MOVING MOTORCYCLE, COUNTRYSIDE AND CITY — CONTINUOUS Franklin and Maria ride with Maria’s suitcase strapped to back of the bike - along the road and then into the city. weaves in and out of traffic and finally pulls over at... EXT. / INT. PHARMACY — CONTINUOUS ...a perfectly ordinary pharmacy in the middle of the cit Franklin accompanies Maria inside and nods hello to the PHARMACIST behind the counter. The pharmacist disappears into the back. The two of them wait.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: And Blanca?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: She’s in another place. The sliding door-display case suddenly rolls open - revea the pharmacist standing behind it expectantly. Franklin passes him Maria’s suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (reading her nervousness) Don’t worry. Everything’s gonna be fine. He gives her a kiss on the cheek. She hesitates before turning away from him and follows the pharmacist into the back. INT. PHARMACY, BACK ROOM — CONTINUOUS The pharmacist leads Maria into a small, stark room with table, a few chairs, a sink and a small bed in the corner (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: At the other end of the table is a YOUNG MAN, in his 20s. He's got various paraphernalia spread out in front of him BOX OF SEVERAL DOZEN RUBBER SURGICAL GLOVES, a pair of SCISSORS, a ROLL OF PLASTIC WRAP, a DIGITAL SCALE, a smal box of DENTAL FLOSS, a BOTTLE OF SALAD OIL, a SMALL BOWL two bags of HEROIN. He transfers a precise amount of heroin from the scale in the severed finger of a latex glove, which he then places into a HAND-OPERATED PRESS, pumping the lever and packing down into a dense one-inch capsule. The pharmacist steps out of the room as Maria sits and watches the young man, entranced...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He cuts the fingers off several of the rubber gloves. He slides the heroin capsule into a rubber finger and packs all the way down into the bottom. He takes the finger full of heroin and stuffs it inside a second rubber finger — then another and another until it' been buried in SIX LAYERS of rubber fingers. He breaks off a piece of DENTAL FLOSS and ties it shut li rubber balloon. He then trims off the excess dental floss and the excess rubber. He sets the "pellet" down — a snug little thumb-sized pac — and begins making another. The pharmacist re-enters the room, breaking Maria’s tranc He hands her two small PILLS and a cup of water.

dialogues.speaker: PHARMACIST
dialogues.text: This will stop your bowels. She puts the pills in her mouth and swallows them. The pharmacist then raises a bottle of RED LIQUID with a tube an atomizer attached. PHARMACIST (cont’d) Open you mouth. As he sprays the liquid into Maria’s throat, JAVIER steps and sits down at the table with her. The pharmacist finis and leaves the room. Javier pulls the SMALL BOWL over to him and pours it full SALAD OIL. He takes one of the pellets and dips it in the oil, completely covering it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He passes it to Maria and she puts it in her mouth. She tries to swallow it but GAGS.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: Relax. She puts the pellet back in her mouth and sets it deep in throat with her fingers.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't put your fingers in so much. Maria starts to gag again.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you practice with the grapes?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: If you can't do this we'll stop now.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: No, really. I can do it. Just give me a second. Maria looks nervous. She puts the pellet in her mouth and holds it there.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: Just let it slide down. She tilts her head back and the pellet goes down. She loo very relieved.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: See.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: Good. He dips another pellet in oil and holds it out to her. AN HOUR LATER - Maria paces around the room. The young ma packs up his stuff as Maria and Javier continue to work.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How do you feel?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: How many is it so far? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: Twenty-three. Maria presses her stomach.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here. Lay down on the bed. She lays down. Javier places his hands on her stomach.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: What are you doing?!

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: They have to settle properly. He massages her stomach, manipulating the pellets inside. The door opens and the PHARMACIST brings in a bowl of SOU

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have some soup. Maria gets up and sits at the table. She takes a spoonful soup with great trepidation. It hurts going down.

dialogues.speaker: PHARMACIST
dialogues.text: Do you want more anesthetic? Maria shakes her head No. Javier places another pellet in bowl. She gets it on her spoon along with some soup and stares at it. A FEW HOURS LATER - the room is illuminated by early afternoon light. Maria sits at the table with her head do Javier is holding out a pellet.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: One more.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: How many?

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: Sixty-two. Come on. She stares at him hatefully before taking the pellet. She swallows it slowly but without gagging.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good... I'll be right back. He turns and leaves the room. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Maria takes a beat alone. She goes to her things and remo from her purse a toothbrush and a small tube of toothpast She goes to the sink and brushes her teeth. She rinses an spits and then catches sight of herself in the mirror. Javier comes back in, sits at the table, and removes from wallet a wad of AMERICAN MONEY - 20-dollar bills. She sit

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (hands her the money) This is eight hundred dollars. Maria stares at the money. Never in her life has she held this much. JAVIER (cont'd) When they ask you how much you're coming to America with tell them eight hundred dollars. Just say you've been saving up. (handing her papers) This is your ticket. Round trip - one week. This is your passport and visa. She stares at them - fascinated. He writes something on a piece of PAPER and passes it to her.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (reads, mispronouncing) Motor Lodge 46.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: That's the name and address of the hotel where you say you’re staying. Do you remember why you’re in America?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I'm on vacation.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: (testing her) And how long are you here for?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: One week.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: Who bought this ticket?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: A friend of mine.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: Where? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: At a travel agency on Plaza Bolivar.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: Where do you plan to stay in America?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I’m going to stay in a hotel.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: Which hotel?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (reading) Motor Lodge 46.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: Good. How are you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Like hungry but full - it’s weird.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: You can drink on the plane but don’t eat or it’ll make your stomach release acid. Don’t talk to anyone on the plane. Even the stewardesses spy for the DEA. Once you've been passed through Customs you'll come out through an electric sliding door. On the other side of that there'll be someone there to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: How will I know who it is?

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: They'll know you. If they're not there for some reason call this number. He takes back the paper and writes a TELEPHONE NUMBER on

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The key is to stay calm and act like nothing’s wrong. But if you do get caught just keep quiet. (he leans in) If you give them any information we'll leave you to rot in there while we go to your house and have a chat with your grandmother, your mother, your sister... and little Pachito. Same thing if any of what's in your stomach disappears along the way. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We know exactly how much each one of those 62 pellets you've got weighs. Do I make myself clear? He glares into her eyes. The effect is chilling. INT. AIRPORT, X-RAY CHECK POINT — AFTERNOON Maria puts her purse on the conveyor belt and steps throu the metal detector. One guard scans her up and down with HANDHELD METAL DETECTOR and another then pats her down. A Maria stares straight ahead she suddenly sees something o BLANCA - dressed vampy with cleavage and lipstick - brows perfume at the duty-free shop. They make brief eye contac

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. AIRPLANE CABIN — LATER Maria gazes out the window as the plane picks up speed. S crosses herself and mutters a Hail Mary. She closes her e as her back is pressed up against the seatback and the pl becomes airborne. For the first time in her life, she is the surface of the planet, flying. She stares out and watches with fascination as the world shrinks away below

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: The fasten seat belt sign is turned off with a soft CHIME The woman next to her (Carolina) undoes her seat belt and gets up. Maria looks over at the people on the other side of the aisle. When she looks forward she is surprised to see LUC getting up and making her way to the aisle. Maria unbuckles her seatbelt and then approaches Lucy, wh getting a pillow and a blanket out of the overhead bin.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (hushed) I didn't know you were going again.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: I didn't either. It just happened.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: You know we’re not the only ones. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: That's how it works. They send a bunch of us so if one gets stopped it makes it easier for the rest to slip through...

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Oh... A STEWARDESS suddenly passes behind them. They are both immediately silent. Lucy moves back to her seat.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Maria looks through the IN-FLIGHT MAGAZINE at all the pictures: a spread on Disneyland, a photograph of a businessman in a chic office...and then the MAP OF THE WO with all of the airline’s flight paths indicated. The DINNER CART is maneuvered slowly down the aisle. Carolina pulls her airplane headphones out of one ear.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINA
dialogues.text: It's about time. I'm starved. The stewardess approaches.

dialogues.speaker: STEWARDESS
dialogues.text: Chicken or beef?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINA
dialogues.text: Chicken.

dialogues.speaker: STEWARDESS
dialogues.text: For you?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: ..-Chicken, please. The stewardess turns to get the trays.

dialogues.speaker: STEWARDESS
dialogues.text: Here you are. And now Maria finds herself staring at a perfectly delici looking tray of steaming hot food. The woman next to her unwraps her fork and decides to strike up conversation.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINA
dialogues.text: Do you go to the United States a lot?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Well... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Maria cuts off a piece of chicken and puts it in her mout She chews but doesn’t swallow. Her neighbor is more interested in talking than in listening.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINA
dialogues.text: I go every year to visit my daughter. She married an American and they’ve got a beautiful house on Long Island. Of course, I think the children should be the ones to come to Colombia to visit their grandmother instead of the other way around... The woman TALKS and TALKS - oblivious to whether Maria is fact eating or not. Maria carefully spits her food out into her napkin.

dialogues.speaker: LATER -
dialogues.text: Maria is reaching up playing with the buttons and nozzles trying to figure out how to control the air. The seats ne to her are empty. Suddenly, BLANCA is standing in the aisle. She looks over her shoulder and quickly sits down in the empty seat next Maria.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: I saw you talking to that woman before. Who was she?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (hesitates) She's... you know...

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: You see that woman... Maria leans forward and spots a woman (CONSTANZA) sitting row back on the aisle. BLANCA (cont'd) I met her before, through Franklin. (beat) So what were you two talking about? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: She said if one of us gets stopped at Customs it creates a distraction for the others to pass.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: So who’s going to go first?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Whoever.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: I don’t want to go first. I’11 wait and see what happens to her.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I thought we were supposed to go right through without waiting... Beat.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: «+I feel like when I’ve got my period.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: .+.-I feel like I need to go the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Excuse me! Carolina is standing in the aisle, looking annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: (getting up) Sorry. As Carolina settles back into her seat Maria places her pillow under her ear and closes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: LUCY - she sits in her seat dabbing her forehead with a napkin. The cabin lights are dimmed, the in-flight movie playing. Maria wakes up. Carolina has fallen asleep with her headphones on. Maria lifts her shirt and presses her abdomen in discomfo She unbuttons her pants trying to relieve the pressure. She climbs over Carolina and moves to the aisle. CONSTANZ looks up at her as she passes.  47. INT. AIRPLANE LAVATORY — CONTINUOUS Maria locks the LAVATORY door and the lights come on. She pulls down her pants and sits on the toilet. As she conto her face we hear the TINKLE of urine on metal. INT. AIRPLANE CABIN — CONTINUOUS LUCY is sweating profusely, still dabbing herself with a napkin. She doesn't look well. She gets up and maneuvers the aisle. INT. LAVATORY — CONTINUOUS Sitting on the toilet, Maria suddenly has a look of PANIC her eyes. Desperately she grabs paper towels from the dispenser. IN THE PLANE CABIN — Lucy walks slowly down the aisle. Sh sees Blanca. The two of them lock eyes, but Lucy keeps walking. IN THE LAVATORY — Maria holds her hand under cold water i the sink. She's rinsing off TWO PELLETS. She opens her purse and removes her tube of TOOTHPASTE. PLANE CABIN — Lucy comes to the back of the plane and wai by the lavatory, looking sicker all the time. LAVATORY — Maria squeezes toothpaste onto the second pell smears it on and takes a beat. She puts the pellet in her mouth, tilts her head back and swallows. She then looks a herself in the mirror and tries to compose herself. PLANE CABIN - Maria comes out of the lavatory, face to fa with LUCY. Lucy looks desperate — sweating, nervous.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: I don't feel well.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: What are you going to do? Lucy has a blank, nervous look on her face.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Calm down. As soon as we arrive we're going to get you to a doctor. You’re going to be fine. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: (pulling it together) I know. I know. (beat) Thanks. Maria heads back up the aisle - past Blanca - to her seat casting a glance over her shoulder as she sits.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: The STEWARDESS works her way down the aisle with a stack YELLOW CUSTOMS CARDS. She gives them to Maria and Carolin Maria reads the card and gets to a blank space for an ADD where she plans to stay in the U.S. She reaches into her pocket for the paper with the name of the hotel but she c find it. She searches all her pockets and then in her pur but the paper is nowhere. She looks over to copy her neighbor’s answer but Carolina finishes writing and tucks the card away. Maria gets up and walks forward to the middle Emergency E and turns to look at Lucy. Lucy, looking still worse, notices Maria and gets concerned. She glances over her shoulder, gets up and makes her way over to Maria. LUCY (cont'd) (hushed) I've been thinking about telling the stewardess I'm sick. They could get me a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: But you'll end up in jail once they find out what's wrong with you.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: But I'll be alive.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (hesitates) Don't. Just wait. Lucy looks thankful to Maria for supporting her.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...-I lost the name the hotel. Do you have it? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: No. I always give them my sister’s address. (beat) Do you have a pen? Maria gives her a pen - Lucy tears off a corner of her ti envelope.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (scribbling) It's my sister's address in Queens, New York...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: NEW YORK SKYLINE AT NIGHT. Blanca looks out her window. L meanwhile touches up her make-up trying to hide how sick is. Maria looks out her window playing nervously with the crucifix on her necklace. INT. AIRPORT CORRIDORS — NIGHT Lucy comes off the plane amid Constanza and other passeng Maria walks down the same corridor. Blanca follows Maria. INT. BAGGAGE CLAIM / CUSTOMS AREA — CONTINUOUS Maria stands by a large baggage carousel with other passengers from the plane. She spots Blanca and Constanza various points across from her. Lucy stands about ten fee away from her - looking sick but doing her best to keep h nerves under control. There are about FIFTEEN CUSTOMS INSPECTORS across the roo men and women — looking bored, talking among themselves a they wait for passengers to come through. Bags tumble down the chute - some huge, some swathed in plastic wrap. They get clogged on the carousel. Three AIRPORT BAGGAGE HANDLERS unknot them. Passengers struggle pull their luggage off and head through Customs. Blanca t her bag off and lingers — as if waiting for a second bag. Lucy pulls a SMALL RED SUITCASE off. She looks at Maria — and then steps to the short line by the first two inspect Maria looks down but there’s no sign of her suitcase. Lucy — nervous and sick — hands her yellow card to the inspector. He gives her a quick look and waves her throug (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Everyone breathes a sigh of relief. Lucy makes eye contact with Maria from the other side — a then passes outside through a sliding electric door. Constanza steps up to an inspector. The inspector asks he something and then points to the secondary inspection poi She looks mortified as she takes her bag over to be check Blanca sees this, takes her bag and proceeds directly to Customs. Maria looks desperate for her bag to come around Blanca gets at the end of the line at Customs. At last, M grabs her bag off the carousel. She begins to move toward the line but before she even gets there she is stopped by roaming INSPECTOR - a tall man with a buzz cut.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: (in English) Hello. May I see your passport, ticket and declaration card? Maria stares at him blankly.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (repeating, in Spanish) May I see your passport, ticket and declaration card? Maria — containing her fear — hands over her documents. T inspector looks at them. INSPECTOR (cont‘d) Where are you coming from today?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Colombia.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: And where are you traveling to?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: New York.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Are these all your bags?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Yes. The inspector takes a beat. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Would you mind coming with me? Maria follows the inspector as they go directly to the inspection counter opposite Constanza. Maria looks over a sees Blanca being waved right through.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Place your suitcase on the counter... Open it, please. Maria does so. The inspector puts on a pair of RUBBER GLOVES, opens it up and begins to check its contents, pil up Maria’s clothes. Throughout, the inspector invokes a strangely casual, friendly tone.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s the purpose of your stay?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Vacation.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: How long will you be here?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: One week. The inspector feels all the sides of the suitcase. A SECOND INSPECTOR - a Latina woman - walks up and watche the first agent continues his inspection.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Only a week? No more?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Where will you be staying?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: ..-With my friend.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Where does your friend live? The inspector finds a pair of shoes and checks the soles bending them, looking closely at the heels. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Maria looks beyond him, at the opposite counter, and watc CONSTANZA answer questions - the contents of her suitcase piled up.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (looking up, repeating) Where does your friend live?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: New York.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Is she coming to pick you up today?

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: And how are you going to get there?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Uh... In a taxi.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: And this is all your luggage?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Yes. He finishes going through her things and takes another lo at her paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Thank you very much. Sorry to bother you. Have a good stay in New York. Maria, still nervous, re-arranges the clothes in her suit and is starting to shut it when the second agent speaks u

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: (in English) She looks nervous. (to Maria) You look nervous.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: (translating) She says you look nervous.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: ...No. I’m not. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) Why do you look so nervous?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: But I’m not. The second inspector stares at her hard. Maria shifts her gaze nervously from one to the other as if looking for he from the first inspector. INT. INTERROGATION ROOM — CONTINUOUS The male inspector and female inspector lead Maria into a sterile, little room — about eight by eight - bare except the counter and a wooden BENCH. The female inspector stan behind her.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Place your hands on the wall... Higher... Open your legs... Don’t take your hands off the wall. Maria does as she says. The inspector pats Maria down — t arms, the back, the breasts, stomach, crotch, and legs, f and back.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Please, have a seat. Maria sits down on the bench.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Give me both your shoes, please. Maria does as he says. The inspector checks each carefull and then pierces the sole of one with a sharp awl as the Female Inspector continues questioning Maria.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Maria Alvarez. Is that your name?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Eighteen. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Is this your first time in this country?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: And where are you staying?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: ..-With my sister. The Female Inspector looks at the first Inspector.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: But before you said you were going to stay with a friend. Which is it, with your sister or with your friend?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: ..-With my sister. The male inspector sets her shoes aside.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: If we call her would she confirm that you’re coming to visit?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: .-.She doesn’t know I’m coming. I was going to surprise her. We haven’t seen each other in four years.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: And you're going to show up, just like that...? How do you know she'll be there...? What if she’s not home? Where will you stay?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: ..-I don’t know... In a hotel...

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: And how much money do you have?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Eight hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Who bought this ticket?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I did. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: How much did it cost?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: ...Like five hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: You’re not sure? The inspectors look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Tell me, Maria, what do you do in Colombia?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Me...? I work in a flower plantation.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Doing what exactly?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Dethorning roses.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: So how did you get the money for the ticket and the eight hundred dollars?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I saved up.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: And you're here for...

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Vacation.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: You know what - I don’t believe you're really here on vacation. Do you have some other reason for coming? Are you maybe bringing something into the United States?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Do you want to know what I think? I think you're bringing drugs into this country.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: No. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: We have seen cases of people who carry drugs inside their bodies. Are you carrying drugs in your stomach?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: (beat) I want you to prove it to me. I want you to take an X-ray. She stares at Maria but Maria doesn’t flinch. She then go to the counter and takes a sheet of paper from a stack.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Please sign this document permitting us to perform an X-ray. She gives Maria the form.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I don't read English.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: It's there in three languages. Maria reads the form, takes a beat and then signs it (printing her name like a child). The inspectors watch he carefully.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (playing the good cop) Maria, listen, I’m going to be straight with you. If we do this X-ray and you’re carrying drugs then we’re going to see it immediately. In that case it would be much, much better to tell us now. That way we can tell the judge you cooperated and you'll get less time in jail.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: If you make us take the X-ray and you are carrying then you’1l get ten years in prison. Minimum.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Please Maria, tell us the truth. We can’t help you if you don’t help us...

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: .+.I’m not carrying anything. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The two inspectors look at one another trying to decide w to do. INT. BATHROOM — CONTINUOUS In a tiny, white-tiled institutional bathroom the female inspector hands Maria a PLASTIC CUP. In front of the inspector Maria hikes up her skirt, sits the toilet and pees into the cup. INT. MEDICAL FACILITY — MAIN AREA Maria sits in a corridor waiting. A door opens. CONSTANZA steps out followed by another inspector who sits her down opposite Maria. The two of them stare at each other. Constanza's eyes are puffy and red. She's clearly been crying. Through the open door, Maria can see in a white-coated TECHNICIAN examining an X-ray with another inspector. He takes out a pen and points to something. There are scores pellets clearly visible in Constanza’s stomach and intestines. The inspector takes the X-ray and walks over to Constanza He handcuffs Constanza and leads her down the hall. Maria looks absolutely petrified. Thirty feet away the tw inspectors that accompanied her are discussing something another white-coated technician. They turn and look at Ma and shake their heads — something is wrong. They walk toward Maria conversing with each other IN ENGL

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: (in English) What do you think...?

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: (in English) Given the circumstances...? Maria tries to glean what they’re saying. They stare at h

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Maria, in Spanish) Do you know that you’re pregnant? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: ...Yes. (beat) Will the X-ray hurt my baby?

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: We don’t X-ray pregnant women.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: But we can detain them... She says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Maria, it’s clear you didn’t buy this ticket yourself. We know you couldn’t have saved up all this money. Tell us the truth - who bought this ticket?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: ...The truth is a friend bought it for me.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: What’s your friend’s name?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Franklin... He’s my boyfriend. He’s the father of my baby.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: And he gave you the eight hundred dollars, too?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Yes... for the baby.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: (testing Maria once more) ...And does he know you swallowed drugs?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: But I didn’t. (beat) I’m not carrying drugs. I’m just here to see my sister. I haven’t seen her in four years... I swear.
