The inspectors stare at each other trying to make a decis  59. INT. AIRPORT ARRIVALS TERMINAL — LATER Maria steps through the sliding door and into the waiting area with her suitcase. There are a small number of peopl waiting on the side of the ropes. Maria walks slowly thro them, scanning the crowd for her contact. No-one approach her. EXT. AIRPORT TERMINAL — CONTINUOUS Maria carries her bag out to the curb to look around. She sees a row of PAY PHONES and walks over to them. She’s contemplating what to do when suddenly her elbow is grabb from behind. A TALL GUY (WILSON) pulls Maria along, taking her suitcas his other hand. He drags her into the street where a VAN waiting. He opens the sliding door, throws her inside and slams the door shut behind her. INT. VAN — CONTINUOUS Totally spun around, Maria finds herself sitting next to and BLANCA. There are TWO GUYS (CARLOS and WILSON) in the front - they look very YOUNG, not more than 20, and have very nervous quality.

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: (to Maria) What happened to the other one?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: They arrested her.

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: Fuck! Wilson starts the engine and pulls away fast. Maria looks Lucy, clearly ill, and then at Blanca. INT. HOTEL ROOM — CONTINUOUS (NIGHT) The door opens - Wilson enters and flips on the light. Th room is spare - two queen-sized beds and a TV. He sets down Lucy’s suitcase and goes to shut the blinds while the girls enter. Carlos sits in a chair, sets down PLASTIC BAG and begins emptying his pockets. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: Make yourselves comfortable. You'll be here until you shit everything out. Maria and Lucy sit together on the edge of the bed. Blanc also sits.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: You have to get a doctor for her.

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: What are you talking about, doctor?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: She's sick.

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: It doesn't make any difference to me.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: She needs medicine.

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: (cutting her off) Shut up! He reaches into the bag and throws down FOIL PACKS OF TABLETS.

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Take those. Lucy grabs for one of the foil packets greedily.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: What are they?

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: A laxative. To speed things up.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: (standing) I have to go to the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: Here. He removes a small box from the plastic sack and passes L two RUBBER GLOVES. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CARLOS (cont'd) Don’t use the toilet. I don’t want anything accidentally going down the drain. And don’t forget the toothpaste - I don’t want to be smelling your shit. She goes into the bathroom and shuts the door. Carlos mov over to the bed and makes himself comfortable. INT. HOTEL ROOM — LATER (NIGHT) Blanca sits at the side of the bed - notices a matchbook picks it up. INT. HOTEL ROOM — BATHROOM - SAME TIME (NIGHT) In the BATHROOM, Maria squats in the bathtub. JUMP CUT: Maria smears toothpaste on the pellets one by on and pile them by the sink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning light burns through the curtains. Blanca comes out of the bathroom with a handful of pellet puts them in her ziplock bag (two others on the dresser) counts them through the plastic. Wilson lies on the bed watching TV. Maria lies on her bed also watching. Carlos sits over by the window rolling himself a joint. Lucy squats at her suitcase folding a shirt - moving slow Maria keeps one eye on her, one on the TV. She glances at Wilson. Lucy sits on the chair and takes a deep breath. Without blinking, Wilson clicks the remote a few times an lands on something else: a news report (in Spanish) about crowds of people flocking to see an apparition of the Vir on the side of a tree. As the news report ends, Wilson crosses himself, kisses his crucifix and tucks it under h shirt. Blanca crosses the room, causing Maria to notice that Luc has dozed off sitting up.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Lucy! Lucy! LUucy!!!!  62. INT. HOTEL ROOM — BATHROOM — MOMENTS LATER In the bathroom, Maria holds Lucy’s head under COLD WATER the bathtub. She turns off the water and dries Lucy’s hai vigorously as a way of keeping her awake. Maria and Lucy sit still on the edge of the tub. They hav long moment in silence. Maria strokes her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dim bed-side light. The guys sit drinking beers - Wilson watching TV while Carlos plays with a GAMEBOY. Lucy sits up in bed with her eyes barely open, on the TV. Blanca sits up on the other side of the bed. Maria comes out of the bathroom, makes eye contact with L and then sits on the edge of the bed next to Blanca.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: (somber ) ..-How are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: «+OK.... You? Blanca nods, looks at the TV. Maria looks at her then awa again. INT. HOTEL ROOM — NEXT MORNING CLOSE-UP on Maria sleeping. We hear the sound of HUSHED, AGITATED VOICES off screen, movement - there’s a shaft of light as the bathroom door opens and then closes. Maria rolls over and opens her eyes a crack, slow to adjust. In MARIA'S POV — we see the two guys — one of them appear carry LUCY in his arms. Maria sits up a little, rubs her eyes and refocuses. And in another snippet of MARIA'S POV — we see the two gu carrying Lucy, ARGUING in a panicked whisper as they leav the hotel room and shut the door behind them. Maria is totally unsure of what she's seen in her half- sleeping-state. She sits up in bed. The room is strangely quiet - the two guys are gone, Lucy is gone. Only Blanca next to her asleep. She gets up and goes to the bathroom.  63. INT. HOTEL ROOM — BATHROOM — CONTINUOUS (MORNING) Maria treads cautiously into the bathroom and then stops in her tracks. She SHRIEKS at what she sees: there’s BLOO all over the bathtub.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Blanca! BLANCA!

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. HOTEL ROOM — MOMENTS LATER Maria, frantically grabbing their bags of PELLETS and throwing them in her suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: We can’t stay here?

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (glares at her) Don’t you get it? They did something to Lucy? Everything’s totally fucked up. We have to get out of here before they come back. Maria closes up her suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: But...

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Hurry up!!

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. HOTEL ROOM / PARKING LOT — CONTINUOUS Blanca and Maria come out of the room - each with her sma suitcase - and run across the parking lot.  64. EXT. STREET, GAS STATION — CONTINUOUS Maria and Blanca continue running until they’re completel out of breath - standing at the side of the road by a gas station. EXT. STREET, GAS STATION — LATER Maria and Blanca sit on their luggage by the gas station, watching traffic.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: Did you finish getting all your pellets out? Maria nods.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where are we? This doesn’t look like New York. (Maria doesn’t answer) What are we going to do?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Blanca, stop. Just let me think for a minute, will you. Maria stares at the ground between her feet. Then, withou saying anything, she opens her purse and begins rummaging EXT. GAS STATION — MOMENTS LATER Maria walks toward the ATTENDANT, a Filipino guy in his 2 washing the windshield of a customer's car.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (in Spanish, miming) Excuse me. To make a call. She shows him the PAPER with LUCY’S SISTER’S ADDRESS and phone number.

dialogues.speaker: ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: (mocking, in English) Me no speak Spanish.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (holds out the paper) A call. Telephone. I don’t know how to use the telephone. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: No Espafiol. Get it? He walks away to remove the pump from the car. She follow him. The customer - a HAITIAN DRIVER in his 30s - stands the back of the car.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Can you tell me how to call this number? The attendant takes the paper and reads it.

dialogues.speaker: ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Queens, New York. You gotta go into New York. You gotta take a bus. (as if to a child) Bus. You know? He hands the paper back to her. She watches the driver pa

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: (in English) You trying to go to New York? To Queens? (points to the paper) To Queens?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (looks at the paper) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: You want a ride? You, with me, drive. To Queens. He points to his car which in fact looks like a taxi.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: No, thank you. I want to make a call.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: I‘1l take you. Off the meter. No problem. Sixty bucks. It’s OK... Taxi... See? Taxi... Maria looks at him, at the taxi. INT. MOVING CAR, PULASKI SKYWAY — CONTINUOUS Maria stares out the window at New Jersey factories and refineries. It looks entirely different from her pastoral homeland - gray and dark and forbidding. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Blanca clutches her MATCHBOOK - everything about her feel guarded and angry. The driver is having a conversation in CREOLE on his cell phone (apparently talking to himself a speaks into a headset). He finishes and looks in the rear view mirror.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: (in English) You just arrive in the United States...? This your first time here? Maria looks at Blanca.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: What's he saying?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I have no idea.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Where are you from...? D’ot venez- vous...? De donde?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: From Colombia. We’re Colombian.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Colombia! Bueno. Yo hablo espafiol.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: Could you tell us how far it is to that address where we're going?

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: (looks at Maria, at him) Nothing. Never mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they enter a tunnel Maria and Blanca look at each othe Out the other side Maria stares up at skyscrapers, at the yellow taxis, at the people rushing by on Manhattan sidewalks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the cab goes over the bridge, Maria watches the skylin Manhattan recede into the distance.  67.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maria and Blanca look out at Roosevelt Avenue from the ta a Colombian restaurant catches her eye amidst the chaos o activity on the street. EXT. TAXI, CARLA’S BUILDING - MOMENTS LATER AT THE BACK OF THE CAR, the driver opens the TRUNK and Ma takes her bag out. The driver removes Blanca’s.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Sixty dollars. Sesenta.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: (to Maria) Sixty dollars?! You can use your own money - I’m not paying that. Maria takes out her purse - the driver notices her wad of bills. Maria pays.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you sure we’re in the right place?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I think so. She spots an unimpressive apartment building. MARIA (cont'd) I think it’s that one there. Apartment 4,n. Maria crosses to the apartment building.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: (to the driver) Can you wait for a minute? Wait? Un momento?

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: (looks from one to the other) Un momento. The driver goes and stands by his door. Maria stares at a panel full of buttons and finds Aristizabal, 4A. She presses the buzzer. Blanca watches t driver get back in the car to wait. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Maria buzzes again but there’s no answer. The driver HONK and makes a questioning gesture to Maria.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: There’s no answer.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: Let’s go back.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: Lucy’s sister doesn’t even know you. You don’t even know Lucy.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: She invited me to stay with her.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: But what are you gonna say?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I don't know. I'll figure it out.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: I want to go back to the hotel and wait. (holds up the matchbook) I have the address.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I’m not going back there.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: Maria, this is stupid. All we have to do is hand them our pellets and get our money.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: We can't go back there.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: But they're gonna fucking freak when they see we took off. We have to go back.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Don’t you get it? Didn't you see what they did to Lucy? All of the sudden they’re silenced by the sound of the ta SPEEDING OFF down the street, leaving the two of them standing there. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They watch as it disappears around the corner. Maria grab her bag and walks back over to the building, but Blanca continues to stand by the side of the street, angry. As Maria tries the buzzer again an INDIAN WOMAN comes out the building and she catches the door.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Blanca!

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: No. The two of them stare each other down. Blanca folds her a refusing to go in. Finally, Maria, exasperated, turns and goes inside. Blanca grabs her suitcase and begins to carry it up the street. INT. BUILDING STAIRWELL — CONTINUOUS Maria, alone, carries her suitcase up the staircase. She stops at the window and stares out, then sits on the floor by her suitcase. As she stares at the door to Lucy’ sister's apartment TEARS well up in her eyes. She begins cry - BAWLING and TREMBLING like a baby - alone and aband at the end of the long hallway.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. BUILDING HALLWAY — NIGHT Maria sits next to her suitcase at the end of the hallway ASLEEP. Suddenly she wakes to the sound of a DOOR slamming shut. looks up in time to hear the DEADBOLT behind the door to She rubs the sleep out of her eyes, remembers where she i INT. BUILDING HALLWAY — MOMENTS LATER Maria stands in front of 4A, takes a beat and then KNOCKS

dialogues.speaker: PABLO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Who is it? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Hello. I’m looking for Carla Aristizabal. The door opens. Pablo talks through the crack leaving the chain on.

dialogues.speaker: PABLO
dialogues.text: Who’s looking for her?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Maria Alvarez. I’m a friend of her sister's.

dialogues.speaker: PABLO
dialogues.text: Of her sister's?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Yes. Pablo turns inside and talks to someone.

dialogues.speaker: PABLO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: She says she’s a friend of your sister’s... I don’t know... No, come. The door opens to reveal PABLO and CARLA, who looks so mu like Lucy that Maria is startled. The major difference is that she appears to be about eight months PREGNANT.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Hello. Are you Carla Aristizabal?

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: How can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I'm a friend of Lucy’s. I just arrived from Colombia and she asked me to come and say hello for her.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: (skeptical) Lucy did? Really?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Yes. She wanted me to say hello. Carla looks at Pablo.

dialogues.speaker: PABLO
dialogues.text: Come in. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He opens the door for her to come in. She picks up her suitcase and goes inside. INT. APARTMENT — CONTINUOUS They come into a tiny one-bedroom apartment. The living r is being used as a bedroom — with a narrow mattress on th floor, a tiny table and three folding chairs.

dialogues.speaker: PABLO
dialogues.text: Sit. Maria sits at the table. The two of them stay standing.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: What was your name again?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Maria Alvarez.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: And how do you know Lucy?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: ...From town... We live near each other...

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: So tell me, how is Lucy doing? It’s been months since we last spoke.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: She's doing well.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: Is she working?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: ..-Yes... In an office in Bogota... I think like a secretary or something.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: Lucy? A secretary?

dialogues.speaker: PABLO
dialogues.text: See. And you're always talking bad about her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: She talks about you all the time, about how you're expecting a baby, and how happy she is to become an aunt. She’s always talking about coming to visit.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: (sits) Really? And she didn’t send anything with you? A letter or photos or something?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: ...No... The truth is that Lucy gave me your name and told me that if I ever needed anything I could go to you, that you were really nice and sweet and that if I ever had any kind of problem... You see...

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I don’t have any place to stay. Carla looks over at Pablo.

dialogues.speaker: PABLO
dialogues.text: And where were you staying before?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: ...With a friend. The thing is we just got into this really big fight and she kicked me out and now I don’t have anywhere to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: And you don’t have anyone else here? No other friends or family? No-one?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: And you came here all alone?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: And do you have a job yet? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: ..-No, not yet.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: ..-How did you say you knew Lucy?

dialogues.speaker: PABLO
dialogues.text: Carla...

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: Look, it’s not like I’m going to throw her out on the street... It’s just that this is a really small apartment. Pablo and I sleep in the other room and his cousin sleeps in here on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I don’t need a lot of space, really...

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: Yeah but for how long...?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: No, just a few days, no more...

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: And then what?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: No, then I‘’1l find something else. Carla looks at Pablo.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's just for a few days. Really.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. APARTMENT — LATER Pablo blows up an INFLATABLE MATTRESS - the kind intended a swimming pool. He positions it in the corner of the roo and Carla gives him a sheet.

dialogues.speaker: PABLO
dialogues.text: My cousin works in a bakery so he comes home in the middle of the night. Just so you're not startled. Pablo snaps open the sheet and lets it fall on the mattre  74. INT. APARTMENT — NIGHT Maria lies asleep in bed. There’s a KNOCKING on the apartment door which wakes her up. She gets up and goes slowly to the front door.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Who is it? Lucy (0S) It’s Lucy.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Lucy? Lucy (0S) Maria? Maria quickly unbolts the door and opens it. But instead Lucy WILSON and CARLOS from the hotel burst in and pin Ma against the wall. One of them rips at her shirt to reveal her stomach. The man opens his KNIFE and aims at Maria's belly, which suddenly appears NINE MONTHS PREGNANT. He plunges the blade into her stomach. PELLETS pour out of h by the hundreds onto the floor and inside each one is lit fetus. IN BED, Maria wakes suddenly from the NIGHTMARE to the so of the door closing and FOOTSTEPS. She pretends to be asl as Pablo's brother ENRIQUE comes in and turns the light o He notices her lying there and then moves to the mattress Maria opens one eye to see him take off his shirt and the turns away as he slips off his pants. EXT. BUILDING — MORNING Carla leads Maria out of the building and up the street - neighborhood is alive and thumping. Maria glances over he shoulder looking for some sign of Blanca. EXT. / INT. CALLING STORE, QUEENS — MORNING The calling store has various signs in the window - “Llam Internacionales (International Calling)” and “Colombia 18¢/min.” Inside, it’s busy - everyone calling home on Sunday.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: Colombia. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: Number seven. Carla brings Maria into the booth. She dials a number she knows by heart. She listens. The line rings - no-one answ

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: Lucy’s not there. Carla steps out of the booth - Maria is slow to follow.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I want to call my family. Could you help me?

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: «OK. Carla steps in with her, grabs the phone and dials the pr and then hands her the receiver.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now just dial the number... Maria closes herself into the booth, dials carefully and waits for the line to ring. The muffled laughter of anoth conversation filters through the wall behind her.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Hi, granny. It’s me Maria. (her relief is instant) How are you? Is everything OK there?... I’m fine... It’s a good job. The trip was fine... I’m in a small town somewhere near Chiquinquira... I’1l be back in a few days. Are you sure everything is OK there? How’s Pacho?... Is mama there?... She watches Carla through the glass door. EXT. STREET — CONTINUOUS Maria and Carla come out and Carla walks directly to a bl Lincoln Towncar. Pablo gets out, comes around and holds t door open for her.

dialogues.speaker: PABLO
dialogues.text: (off Maria’s look) Oh the car... I work for a car service, as a driver. Get in. He makes a show of opening the door for Maria. She gets i  76. EXT. PARK — LATER A row of about TEN CAR-SERVICE CARS are lined up along on edge of a medium-sized Queens park. There’s a large field few families having barbecues, kids on bikes - mostly Hispanic, some Korean, some Black. There’s a big game of soccer going on across the length o the field. A few women sit in pairs in the grass. Maria a Carla watch the game.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: I used to think I’d be rich if I had two hundred dollars. Here that’s nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: What do you do?

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: I clean offices. It’s nothing glamorous but it’s decent... (beat) Does Lucy really talk about coming to visit? Maria’s face hardens immediately.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: ...Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: You know, I have this fantasy she'll come to see Jorge.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Jorge?

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: (puts her hand on her stomach) That's the name we picked out.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: What if it's a girl?

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: We already know he's a boy.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (laughs) How do you know that? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: From the sonogram... I’ve had it done three times and each time it’s amazing. You watch the baby swimming around inside. The head, the legs. They can see if the baby is healthy.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Really? Maria watches Carla shift her weight to get more comforta Carla sees her staring at her stomach and it makes her sm INT. HALLWAY, CARLA'S APARTMENT BUILDING — LATER Pablo and Carla walk up the stairs to the fourth floor. Maria trails behind. As they move down the corridor towar the apartment Maria sees BLANCA sitting there, waiting.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Where were you last night?!

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: I met a woman who gave me a place... Carla turns to see who Maria's speaking to.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: You two know each other?

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: (to Maria) Is that Lucy’s sister?

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: You know Lucy?

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PABLO
dialogues.text: (to Maria) I thought you said you didn’t know anyone else here.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: The thing is... I told her about Lucy on the trip here. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: So you're not really friends with Lucy.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: It’s just that Maria said she was going to stay with you and I don’t have a place to sleep...

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: You too? I don’t understand. Everyone knows someone in America. Carla looks at Maria - annoyed. Maria looks back - caught EXT. TRAVEL AGENCY — NEXT MORNING Carla leads Maria and Blanca up Roosevelt Avenue and into small storefront travel agency. INT. TRAVEL AGENCY — CONTINUOUS It's a tiny place with posters of Colombia on every wall. the two desks, one is piled with folders and papers, whil the other has the computer of DON FERNANDO, a short man i his 50s, overweight - with a very friendly demeanor. There are about 6 CUSTOMERS crammed in there including an older woman who rubs the pain out of her knees as she wai Don Fernando is talking on the phone and examining a set documents when Carla, Maria and Blanca enter.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: DON FERNANDO
dialogues.text: (looking up) Hello, child. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: (shaking his hand) Fine. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: DON FERNANDO
dialogues.text: (covering phone, to a customer) This notarization is no good. They notarized the cover page but not the copy of your ID. I can tell you they won't accept it like this... (into phone) ...yes, yes, I understand... (to customer) (MORE ) (CONTINUED)
DON FERNANDO (cont'd) Tell them I sent you back and I said not to charge you a second time. They should have done it right to begin with. (to Carla) How is the little one?

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: (hand on her stomach) Fine, thank you...Don Fernando it seems my sister back home sent me a little surprise...This is Maria and Blanca...

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: They just arrived and they don’t know anyone. They’re staying with me but you know how small my place is. I was wondering if you could help...maybe to find some place, and some work for them...

dialogues.speaker: DON FERNANDO
dialogues.text: And you just arrived?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DON FERNANDO
dialogues.text: ...-I can make a few calls... (into phone) .+-No, he didn’t have a pay stub. I have to make one up...

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: Thank you, Don Fernando. (to Maria) He can help you. I have to go to work. You know how to get back? It’s just back down three blocks and around the corner. I’1ll be back tonight after work.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: (trying not to interrupt) Don Fernando, I have to go to work. I’m leaving them here.

dialogues.speaker: DON FERNANDO
dialogues.text: (covering the phone) OK, my child. I’11 see what I can do. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As she leaves, don Fernando signals the girls to take a s INT. TRAVEL AGENCY — LATER Don Fernando wheels his chair around his desk - Maria and Blanca are now sitting across from him. The activity has died down.

dialogues.speaker: DON FERNANDO
dialogues.text: Can you sew?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: A little...not much...

dialogues.speaker: DON FERNANDO
dialogues.text: What did you do back home?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: We worked in flowers.

dialogues.speaker: DON FERNANDO
dialogues.text: There’s a place that sometimes needs women to sew shirts. It’s not like working in flowers but when they need people they don’t check papers so carefully and they pay minimum wage.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: (suddenly) Thank you for your help, don Fernando, but we don’t need jobs. We just need a way to get back to the hotel where we arrived. Blanca opens up her purse, removes a handful of pellets.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (horrified) Blanca...

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: (producing the MATCHBOOK) ...-I have the address of it. We just need a ride.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Blanca, what are you doing? I’m not going back to that hotel.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: I don’t care what you do. I’m sick of following you around. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I never asked you to follow me. I told you not to.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: Bullshit. You were the one that made us leave before we got our money. We have to give the pellets back.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Those guys are dangerous!

dialogues.speaker: DON FERNANDO
dialogues.text: (overpowering them) Quiet. Quiet!... What’s going on? Tell me... What hotel, what money...? (no answer) What have you got there?!

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: (shutting her purse quickly) Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: DON FERNANDO
dialogues.text: Look child. I recognize what those are. Tell me. No response.

dialogues.speaker: DON FERNANDO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Carla doesn’t know, does she... Are you alright, physically?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: But they didn’t pay us. Everything went wrong and they left without paying us and we still have the pellets.

dialogues.speaker: DON FERNANDO
dialogues.text: What do you mean everything went wrong? Blanca won’t answer.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (slowly) Our friend who was with us got sick. I think one of the pellets broke inside her. (tearing up) (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIA (cont'd) I don't know what happened but I think she died or maybe they killed or her. I’m worried about what they did to her. I don’t know what to do...

dialogues.speaker: DON FERNANDO
dialogues.text: Where was it? Blanca passes him the matchbook.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Can you help find our friend?

dialogues.speaker: DON FERNANDO
dialogues.text: I’1l make a few calls and see if the police in New Jersey know anything.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: You can’t call the police.

dialogues.speaker: DON FERNANDO
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, I have a lot of experience in this - I have certain contacts. I know how to handle it.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Please don’t tell Carla. She doesn’t know.

dialogues.speaker: DON FERNANDO
dialogues.text: (angry) Look, I won't say anything to Carla but you have to return those pellets before these people do something to your families back home. Do you understand me? EXT. DON FERNANDO’S, STREET — DAY Blanca and Maria come out of the travel agency onto the street - Blanca racing ahead, angry.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Blanca, I lost the phone number to call in case of emergency? Do you have it?

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: (turns on Maria) What the fuck were you doing in there? I can't believe you said all that shit about Lucy. Now he's going to call the police. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: You know what, Blanca - don't even fucking start with me. What the fuck were you doing waving those pellets in front of his face, telling him what we did.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: What are you doing telling him you want to sew shirts?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I'm dealing with the situation.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: Stupidly.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Then why the fuck are you following me around? Every fucking time I turn around you're following me.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: I thought you knew what you were doing. Obviously I was wrong.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I don't want you here. I don't want to be responsible for you. I'm not your fucking mother, you know.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: I wouldn't want you as my fucking mother. I feel sorry for your baby that it's gonna have such a stupid mother. I mean, swallowing drugs when you're pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: That's pretty fucking stupid. At least I wouldn't do that.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Fuck you. Maria turns and storms off, leaving Blanca there.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: Shit.  84.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maria walks up the boulevard in an angry, confused haze. street is full of people: Hispanic, Chinese, Indian. She peers into various shop windows: a cheap jewelry store; a laundromat; a Colombian coffee shop; a Korean manicure sh an electronics store. She sees a Mexican guy at a corner bodega unpacking flowers from a box that says “Product of Colombia.” She buys an oblea from a street vendor. As she sits and e it she looks across the street. She notices a pregnant wo coming out of a storefront with a sign - in English and i Spanish - “WOMEN’S CLINIC.” INT. MEDICAL CLINIC, WAITING ROOM — CONTINUOUS It's a clean, unpretentious clinic — low-income, but perfectly respectable. Maria stands at the reception wind The RECEPTIONIST herself couldn't be much older than 18, long fake nails and big hair.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: (in Spanish, a bit irritating) You don't have an appointment?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: No...I just...

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: I can make you an appointment for next week.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: It has to be today.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: (she scans the book, annoyed) If you're not in a hurry I might be able to get you in but I can't promise. You'll just have to wait.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: (hands her a clipboard) You need to fill this out. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MARIA SITS, waiting. She looks around the waiting room at the six or seven other women — all Black or Hispanic — so pregnant, one with a year-old baby boy on her lap. INT. EXAMINATION ROOM — DAY It's a relatively small room — an examination table, a si with various bottles next to it. A rack of computer monit and electronic machines is neatly arranged. There’s a sin lamp pointed into the corner of the room. Maria lies on the table wearing a paper gown. A FEMALE DOCTOR sits on a stool next to her taking her blood press

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) You're blood pressure is high. Do you have a history of high blood pressure?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I don't know... Is it a big problem?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Maybe. I don't know yet.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: The doctor spreads a thick jelly on Maria's stomach.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's important that you be very careful while you're pregnant. You must not smoke. And you can't drink alcohol. No beer. No wine. No drugs. Everything you put into your body goes directly into your baby. If you smoke it's like giving a cigarette to your baby. She fiddles with the knobs on one of the monitors, and be to pass the hand unit over Maria's belly. DOCTOR (CONT’D) Let's see. A confusion of gray dots comes onto the screen. DOCTOR (CONT’D) At this stage of the pregnancy you'll be able to see the entire fetus. That's the head. There are the feet. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (amazed) That's my baby?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: (smiling) These are the arms. And these are the legs.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Can you tell me if it's a boy or a girl?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Not yet. The next time you come in we should see it. Maria is entranced by the image of her baby on the screen The doctor hits a few keys on the computer. DOCTOR (CONT’D) There we can see the heart pumping. The blood is flowing well. I'm just going to take a few measurements.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: But everything’s OK, right? It looks healthy?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: So far... Do you want to listen...? To the heart? The doctor taps a few keys and readjust the handpiece. Th room fills with the sound of the baby’s HEARTBEAT - Maria overwhelmed by it.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: CLOSE-UP of a 5x7 hardcopy of the sonogram coming off a printer in the exam room. Maria sits up, buttoning her to button. The doctor hands her the print. She stares at it for a moment — then smiles as tears come to her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (on her way out) I want to see you again in three weeks. I'm concerned about your blood pressure. If it's still high in three weeks then we'll talk about putting you on some medicine. (smiles) And you'll be able to see if it's a boy or a girl. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Thank you. INT. RECEPTIONIST'S DESK — LATER Maria counts out two hundred dollars in twenties.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: (marking in her book) How is Friday the eleventh of next month?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: ...Fine. The receptionist fills in the date on a little REMINDER C and hands it to Maria. INT. TRAVEL AGENCY — LATE AFTERNOON Maria comes into the travel agency. Don Fernando sits alo behind a pile of papers.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: DON FERNANDO
dialogues.text: Come in.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I just wondered if you had any news.

dialogues.speaker: DON FERNANDO
dialogues.text: Sit down...I made a call to the Newark morgue and they had some information... He turns to the fax machine and finds a fax in the pile. DON FERNANDO (cont'd) They received the body of a woman yesterday, found in an abandoned field under the expressway about two miles from that hotel.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: The body...?

dialogues.speaker: DON FERNANDO
dialogues.text: (carefully) Her stomach was sliced open - they think she was a mule. They faxed me this information and a picture of her face... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He hesitates before showing it to her. It is indeed a poo quality, scratchy image of LUCY - her eyes closed, her ja slack. Maria GASPS.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Ay, dios.

dialogues.speaker: DON FERNANDO
dialogues.text: I’m sorry... (beat) I have an undertaker I work with. He’ll go and get her and take care of everything so that she can be sent home to her family for a proper Christian burial... I need to know her name and address back home. Maria is too choked up to speak.

dialogues.speaker: DON FERNANDO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat) What is her name?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: ..-Lucy Diaz.

dialogues.speaker: DON FERNANDO
dialogues.text: Carla’s sister?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Yes, but Carla doesn’t know. She doesn’t even know Lucy was doing it. Lucy wanted to come visit her.

dialogues.speaker: DON FERNANDO
dialogues.text: She has to be told. It’s her sister. Maria sits staring at the fax, in shock. INT. CARLA’S BEDROOM — NIGHT Carla leans back on her bed trying to get comfortable. There’s a BABY CRIB in the room which Maria admires. Pabl in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: This is nice.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: He'll probably sleep with us to start but we saw it on sale. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CARLA (cont'd) (beat) What did don Fernando tell you?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: ...Well...He said maybe he could find me something sewing shirts.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: What was the name of the place?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: (calling to Pablo) Pablo, what was the name of the place where your friend worked, sewing?

dialogues.speaker: PABLO, (0S)
dialogues.text: Frank and Sons, I think.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: (to Maria) That’s it. If it’s Frank and Sons tell him to keep looking for something else. They treat you terribly and then they don’t pay for weeks and weeks. (beat) I asked about a job for you where I work.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: You did?

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: They can’t guarantee work right off but if someone calls in sick then they call you and then eventually if someone quits they might give you a regular job.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (starting slowly) ..-Carla... I don’t really need a job... I’m going back home... Carla actually laughs. Maria is taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: You’re not going back, child. I know how you feel. When I first got here believe me that was all I thought about. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CARLA (cont'd) I remember on my grandmother's birthday I called home and I remember I could hear everyone in the background yelling and laughing and playing music and I remember I was standing there on the street holding the phone with tears streaming down my face. And my sister was asking me, ‘Hey how’s America? Is it wonderful? How is your job?’ And she’s talking about how much she wants to come and be with me. And all I wanted was to tell them how much I missed them and how hard it was here, but then I thought, Who am I to complain about how hard life is here? But it gets better, trust me... The best moment of my life here - was when I got my first paycheck. Oh my god. I will never forget going into that office and sending money home for the first time. You have no idea. Your heart feels so big, so enormous like you can’t keep it in your chest. After a whole life of not being able to do anything suddenly you’re able to help, and then you know they’re counting on you back home, looking up to you and that keeps you going. Carla can’t hold back tears. But the real reason I stay is for my son. He’‘ll have so many more opportunities here. I hate to say it but I can’t imagine bringing up my baby in Colombia now - not with the situation being what it is... It pains me to say it but it’s true... Maria stares at her - not daring to say anything, tears welling up in her eyes. There’s a KNOCK on the front door.

dialogues.speaker: PABLO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I'll get it.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: That must be your friend.  91.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maria and Blanca lie in bed - Blanca acts like she’s igno Maria. Maria sees that Blanca’s got GOLD EARRINGS that sa “Blanca” in cursive.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: What did you do with the pellets?

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: Nothing yet... I just decided I’m at least going to enjoy the money they advanced me... I bought a dress for my mother. (like a little girl) I called her...

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: ...They found Lucy’s body. I sawa picture of her... Blanca looks at Maria, unsure what to say. MARIA (cont'd) It's going to cost two-thousand five- hundred dollars to send Lucy back home... INT. APARTMENT — MORNING Maria, Blanca and Carla sit at the small table eating breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: Help yourself to more arepas. The phone RINGS. Pablo answers it.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (stands, clearing dishes) No, thank you. Maria goes into the kitchen and puts the plates in the si

dialogues.speaker: PABLO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It’s for you. It’s don Fernando. Suddenly Maria looks up.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello, don Fernando. How are you doing?... (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CARLA (0.S.) (cont'd) (slowly Maria’s face changes) ...Arrangements? What arrangements? ..-No, she didn’t say anything... Maria moves to the edge of the kitchen door, listening.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: ...Lucy? What do you mean? Are you sure? Found her here?... I don’t understand. What do you mean? Maria comes into the main room, carefully. Carla is visib upset. CARLA (cont'd) ...They came as what?!

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Carla, let me explain... I tried to tell you. But the words just wouldn’t come out of my mouth...

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: (crying) What are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Lucy got sick. I tried to help her. I swear. But I didn’t know what...

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: When were you going to tell me?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I already spoke to don Fernando. I arranged everything to send Lucy back to Colombia...

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: Arranged? Arranged what?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (getting emotional) Carla, please...

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: (standing up) You’re not arranging anything!

dialogues.speaker: PABLO
dialogues.text: What’s going on...? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: You keep your hands off my sister. You’ve done enough.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: No. You don’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: (hysterical) What have you done? You little bitches!

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Listen to me, please, Carla...

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: You were never her friend! Never!

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (crying) Don’t say that. I tried to help...

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: Get out! Now!

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I tried to help her. I swear.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: Get out!

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: Maria, let’s go.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: (screaming) Get them out already.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Forgive me...

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: Get out!

dialogues.speaker: PABLO
dialogues.text: Please, leave. Pablo tries to calm his pregnant wife.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: Get out! GET OUT!! Maria sobs, not knowing what to do. 93.  94.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maria and Blanca sit in a coffee shop by the window. Mari eyes are puffy - she’s still upset. The two of them just look out at the street without speaking.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: What do you want to do? Maria looks at Blanca. INT. CALLING STORE — LATER The two of them are squeezed into a phone booth in the calling store. Blanca goes through her purse and pulls ou her card with the emergency number and holds it out for M to dial.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: It's ringing...Hello? This is Maria Alvarez... Yes, I’m with her...

dialogues.speaker: SMASH CUT
dialogues.text: EXT. PARKING LOT — LATER

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: (yelling) Where the fuck did you think you were going? Did you think you could just take off? Carlos is yelling right into Maria’s face scary as hell. They're standing next to the van in the far corner of an empty parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: No, but... Wilson grabs Maria and throws her against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: But nothing. Where are the fucking pellets?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: In my suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Come on. Come on. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: With the guy holding her hair Maria goes to her suitcase unzips it. As soon as she pulls out the bag of pellets he grabs it from her.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: Let her go.

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: (in English) Shut the fuck up. He shoves her against the van. CARLOS (cont'd) (in Spanish) Where are yours?

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: In my purse. He grabs her purse from her. Wilson passes Carlos Maria's pellets.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: She should have sixty-two, and the other one should have fifty.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: SAME — LATER Carlos has all of Blanca's pellets piled on the front sea He stands at the open door counting them. Wilson stands next to him, watching.

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: It’s cool. They’re all here.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Good. Wilson moves away, toward the driver side of the van.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: What about our money?

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: (stops, turns) You think we owe you anything? You think you earned it? After you went running from the hotel? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: But we called you.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: You're lucky. I was about to call Javier and tell him you’d made off with the stuff.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: But you got it...

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: Exactly. We’ve got our stuff so now you’re not worth crap.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: But we need that money.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Oh, you do? (laughs) You really need it? He takes a beat, playing with her - then looks over and n to Carlos.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Carlos) Go ahead, man. Carlos unzips a bag and reaches inside and removes TWO ENVELOPES - checks which is which and then gives them to Maria and Blanca. The two of them remove the cash - thick stacks of old fives, tens and twenties

dialogues.speaker: WILSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Make sure it’s all there. (beat) Be sure to tell Javier how nice I was when you get back. You better not make any fucking problems like this on your next run... You’ve been trained now. Wilson turns to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (hesitates, steps forward) What about Lucy's money?

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: (turns) What do you mean, what about Lucy’s money? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I want to give it to her family.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: That's none of your business.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: But you have her pellets.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: You've got nothing to do with that.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: She died doing this. They found her body... I want to give her sister the money so they can send it back to Colombia.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: (hesitates) No, no fucking way.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: She deserves a decent burial. After what you did to her... It’s your responsibility. Carlos advances on Maria aggressively.

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: (stepping in) We don’t have anything to do with that. She knew the risk she was taking. We don’t have any responsibility.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: But she...

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: Shut the fuck up, bitch... Get out of here... Get out!! They stare into each other's faces a beat. The two guys g back into the van and drive off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maria and of sheets

dialogues.speaker: BRIEFCASE
dialogues.text: Blanca sit in Don Fernando’s office next to a pile and blankets on a desk. He is packing up his and taking out his KEYS. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DON FERNANDO
dialogues.text: You should be alright here for the night. I'll be in at seven o’clock in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Thank you for your help.

dialogues.speaker: DON FERNANDO
dialogues.text: I spoke to Carla again in the afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: How was she?

dialogues.speaker: DON FERNANDO
dialogues.text: ..-better... I’m going to lock you in... I’‘1l see you in the morning. He steps out of the office and locks the door behind him. Maria and Blanca stand awkwardly. After a moment, Blanca picks up a blanket and unfolds it in her lap.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: You know, this isn’t the end of it. They're not gonna leave us alone after we get back.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: You don’t know that for sure, Maria. All I want is to get home and see my family.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: There’s something I want to do tomorrow before we leave...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don Fernando brings Maria and Blanca into the foyer of a simple, non-descript funeral home.

dialogues.speaker: DON FERNANDO
dialogues.text: Wait here. He leaves them there - looking at the space. Blanca sits down in an over-stuffed chair.  99.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MORTICIAN brings Maria and don Fernando into a small with a casket. She approaches slowly. He opens the lid an then leaves her alone. Cautiously, Maria approaches. Lucy has been made up - clearly pale and waxen, but presentable. Maria kneels and then weeps softly at her side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The office actually feels more like a living room with la table in the middle. Maria sits with don Fernando countin out several hundred dollars from her envelope. She leaves some of it on the table and hands some to don Fernando.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: And that’s to send Lucy back to Colombia... if that’s what Carla wants... The mortician comes in. Don Fernando looks over at him.

dialogues.speaker: DON FERNANDO
dialogues.text: (to Maria) Excuse me, child. Don Fernando and the mortician step out together, leaving Maria alone. She looks around the room at the display cas full of urns, etc. - with prices tags. Maria collects her purse, gets up and makes her way up th hall and into the viewing room for a final look and sees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CARLA and PABLO standing by the casket. Maria stays by th door, mute. Carla crosses herself at the casket, crying. she turns toward Pablo, she catches sight of Maria.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (explaining herself) I’m sorry. I didn’t mean to upset you. I just wanted to say goodbye to Lucy. I’m going back to Colombia... Carla gazes back at Lucy. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: (slowly) She looks beautiful. Indeed, Carla has been laid to rest in a beautiful white dress. CARLA (cont'd) ...-I don’t understand why she never said anything... We grew so far apart... Maria watches Carla mourn. She doesn’t dare to say anythi INT. MOVING CAR — DAY Maria sits, trancelike, in the back of a moving car-servi car gazing at the Manhattan skyline in the distance. Blan sits across from her. Maria looks down at the PRINTOUT of her sonogram and the REMINDER CARD for her next check-up. EXT. AIRPORT TERMINAL — DAY The driver lifts Maria’s and Blanca’s suitcases out of th trunk along with a large SHOPPING BAG full of Blanca’s ne purchases. INT. AIRPORT TERMINAL — WAITING AREA - CONTINUOUS Maria sits in the waiting area by the gate. She looks at the other people waiting - and then at Blanca who goes through the bag of gifts she’s bringing home.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE GATE -
dialogues.text: Maria stands behind Blanca in line to get on the flight. They advance slowly. Blanca hands over her boarding pass proceeds down the passageway. The gate attendant puts out her hand for Maria’s boarding pass but Maria lets the person behind her go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Blanca... Blanca turns. Maria stares at her, looking for words. They share a mome of understanding. And then Maria turns slowly away from the gate. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The camera holds on her as she walks through the terminal pensive. The sounds of the airport around her begin to dr away. Bit by bit, a certain relief takes over. Her gaze rises a she walks - step by step leaving her past behind, looking forward. Maria moves ahead. A subtle but undeniable flicker of determination in her eyes. FADE OUT.
